title: Level 2 Allergen Awareness
description: Essential training on the 14 major allergens, legal responsibilities (Natasha's Law), and preventing cross-contamination.

modules.title: Introduction & The Law
modules.description: Understanding allergies, intolerances, and legal duties.

slides.title: Why it Matters
slides.content:
## A Growing Issue

- **2 Million**: The number of people in the UK with a diagnosed food allergy.
- **Fatalities**: On average, 10 people die from food-induced anaphylaxis in the UK every year.
- **Your Role**: As a food handler, you are the last line of defence. Your actions can literally save a life.

### The Impact
For allergy sufferers, eating out is a matter of trust. If you break that trust, the consequences can be devastating.

slides.title: What is a Food Allergy?
slides.content:
## The Immune System

A food allergy is when the body's immune system mistakenly attacks a food protein, believing it to be harmful.

### Key Facts:
- **Speed**: Reactions can happen within seconds or minutes.
- **Amount**: Even a microscopic trace (e.g., from a knife) can trigger a reaction.
- **Anaphylaxis**: The most severe reaction, which can cause breathing difficulties and death.

slides.title: Allergy vs Intolerance vs Coeliac
slides.content:
## Know the Difference

### Food Allergy
- **System**: Immune System.
- **Risk**: Life-threatening.
- **Example**: Nut allergy.

### Food Intolerance
- **System**: Digestive System.
- **Risk**: Unpleasant (bloating, pain) but not usually life-threatening.
- **Example**: Lactose intolerance.

### Coeliac Disease
- **System**: Autoimmune.
- **Risk**: Long-term health damage.
- **Action**: Must strictly avoid Gluten.

slides.title: Food Information Regulations 2014
slides.content:
## The 14 Allergens

By law, you must provide accurate allergen information for the **14 Major Allergens**.

### Non-Pre-Packed Food (e.g., Restaurants)
- Information can be written (menu, chalkboard) or verbal.
- If verbal, there must be a sign inviting customers to ask staff.
- You must have a way to check (e.g., an Allergen Matrix or Chef). **Guessing is illegal.**

slides.title: Natasha's Law (PPDS)
slides.content:
## Pre-Packed for Direct Sale

Introduced in 2021 following the death of Natasha Ednan-Laperouse.

### What is PPDS?
Food that is packaged **at the same place** it is sold, **before** the customer orders it (e.g., a sandwich made in the morning and put in a display fridge).

### The Requirement
PPDS food must have a label showing:
1.  **Name of the food**.
2.  **Full ingredients list**.
3.  **Allergens emphasised** (e.g., in **bold**, *italics*, or COLOUR).

slides.title: Consequences
slides.content:
## If You Get It Wrong

### Legal
- **Unlimited Fines**: For the business and individuals.
- **Prison**: Up to 2 years for serious breaches.

### Business
- **Closure**: EHOs can close unsafe businesses.
- **Reputation**: Ruined trust and loss of customers.

### Moral
- **Guilt**: Living with the knowledge that you caused serious harm or death.

start.text: A customer says they are 'a little bit allergic' to nuts. They ask if they can have the satay sauce if you scrape most of it off.

options.label: Yes, if you scrape it well.

wrong.text: ❌ **Incorrect.** Even a microscopic trace can trigger anaphylaxis. You cannot 'scrape off' an allergen.

correct.text: ✅ **Correct.** There is no such thing as 'a little bit allergic'. Never serve a known allergen to an allergic customer.

modules.title: The 14 Major Allergens
modules.description: Detailed breakdown of the 14 allergens you must declare by law.

slides.title: Celery & Cereals
slides.content:
## 1. Celery
- **Found in**: Stocks, soups, salads, spice mixes, Marmite.
- **Includes**: Stalks, leaves, seeds, and celeriac.

## 2. Cereals containing Gluten
- **Wheat**: Bread, pasta, cakes, soy sauce, batter.
- **Rye**: Bread, crackers.
- **Barley**: Beer, malt vinegar, soups.
- **Oats**: Often contaminated with gluten (unless certified GF).
- **Note**: Rice, corn, and potatoes are naturally gluten-free.

slides.title: Crustaceans & Eggs
slides.content:
## 3. Crustaceans
- **Examples**: Prawns, crabs, lobster, crayfish, shrimp, scampi.
- **Found in**: Thai curry pastes, fish soups, paella.

## 4. Eggs
- **Found in**: Cakes, mayonnaise, mousses, pasta, quiche, glazed buns.
- **Note**: Watch out for dried egg powder in mixes.

slides.title: Fish & Lupin
slides.content:
## 5. Fish
- **Found in**: Fish sauce (Thai/Vietnamese), Worcestershire sauce, Caesar dressing, stock cubes.

## 6. Lupin
- **What is it?**: A flower/legume. Seeds are crushed to make flour.
- **Found in**: Some breads, pastries, and pasta (often used as a soya alternative).

slides.title: Milk & Molluscs
slides.content:
## 7. Milk
- **Found in**: Butter, cheese, cream, yogurt, chocolate, glazed buns, powdered soups.
- **Note**: Lactose-free milk still contains milk protein (casein), so it is **NOT** safe for milk allergy sufferers.

## 8. Molluscs
- **Examples**: Mussels, clams, oysters, scallops, snails, squid, octopus.
- **Found in**: Oyster sauce, fish stews.

slides.title: Mustard & Nuts
slides.content:
## 9. Mustard
- **Forms**: Liquid, powder, and seeds.
- **Found in**: Curries, marinades, salad dressings, sauces, soups.

## 10. Nuts (Tree Nuts)
- **Examples**: Almonds, hazelnuts, walnuts, cashews, pecans, brazils, pistachios, macadamia.
- **Found in**: Pesto, marzipan, cakes, Asian dishes, ice cream.
- **Note**: Peanuts are **NOT** tree nuts.

slides.title: Peanuts & Sesame
slides.content:
## 11. Peanuts
- **Type**: A legume (grown underground).
- **Found in**: Satay sauce, cakes, biscuits, groundnut oil, curry pastes.
- **Note**: Refined peanut oil *may* be safe, but unrefined is not. Always check.

## 12. Sesame Seeds
- **Found in**: Hummus (tahini), bread rolls, stir-fries, gomashio.

slides.title: Soya & Sulphites
slides.content:
## 13. Soya
- **Found in**: Tofu, edamame, soy sauce, miso, textured vegetable protein (vegetarian mince), bean curd.

## 14. Sulphur Dioxide (Sulphites)
- **Use**: A preservative.
- **Found in**: Dried fruit (apricots, raisins), wine, beer, soft drinks, sausages, burgers.
- **Limit**: Must be declared if >10mg/kg.

start.text: A customer with a nut allergy asks if the pasta with pesto is safe.

wrong.text: ❌ **Incorrect.** Traditional pesto contains pine nuts or cashews/walnuts.

correct.text: ✅ **Correct.** Pesto usually contains nuts (Tree Nuts) and cheese (Milk).

slides.title: How it Spreads
slides.content:
## Direct vs Indirect

- **Direct**: Removing nuts from a salad but serving the salad (traces remain).
- **Indirect**: Using a knife to cut peanut butter toast, then wiping it and using it for a cheese sandwich.
- **Fryers**: Cooking chips in the same oil as battered fish (Gluten/Fish contamination).
- **Steam**: Frothing milk for a cappuccino on a wand used for soy milk.

slides.title: Control Measures
slides.content:
## The Purple Rule
Purple is the standard colour for 'Allergen Free' equipment in kitchens.

### Best Practices:
- **Storage**: Store allergens in sealed containers, ideally below non-allergens (to prevent spills).
- **Hand Washing**: Wash hands thoroughly before preparing an allergen-free meal.
- **Equipment**: Use separate chopping boards, knives, and pans.
- **Cleaning**: A 'quick wipe' is not enough. Use a two-stage clean (clean then sanitise) with a fresh cloth.

start.text: A customer needs Gluten Free chips. You have one fryer used for everything.

options.label: Cook them in a separate pot/oven.

wrong.text: ❌ **Incorrect.** The oil is contaminated with batter (flour/gluten) from other items.

correct.text: ✅ **Correct.** You must use a dedicated gluten-free cooking method.

slides.title: Taking the Order
slides.content:
## Never Guess

If a customer mentions an allergy:
1.  **Listen**: Take it seriously.
2.  **Check**: Consult the Allergen Matrix or Chef. Do not rely on memory.
3.  **Confirm**: Tell the kitchen clearly ("Table 4, Severe Nut Allergy").
4.  **Deliver**: Ensure the meal goes to the right person.

### "May Contain"
Manufacturers use this to warn of cross-contamination risks in their factories (e.g., "May contain traces of nuts"). You must pass this information to the customer so they can decide.

start.text: The chef changes the brand of mayonnaise. What should you do?

wrong.text: ❌ **Incorrect.** The new brand might use mustard flour or different oil.

slides.title: Signs & Symptoms
slides.content:
## Anaphylactic Shock
A severe, life-threatening reaction.

### Symptoms:
- **Airway**: Swollen tongue, difficulty swallowing, throat tightness.
- **Breathing**: Wheezing, difficulty breathing, noisy breathing.
- **Circulation**: Pale/clammy skin, faintness, collapse.
- **Skin**: Hives (nettle rash), flushing, swelling (angioedema).
- **Other**: Sense of impending doom.

slides.title: Action Plan
slides.content:
## What to Do

1.  **Call 999**: Ask for an ambulance and say "Anaphylaxis".
2.  **EpiPen**: If the patient has an Adrenaline Auto-Injector (AAI), help them use it. Usually injected into the outer thigh.
3.  **Position**: Lie the patient flat with legs raised. **Do not stand them up** (this can stop the heart).
4.  **Repeat**: If no improvement after 5 minutes, use a second AAI if available.

start.text: A customer collapses and struggles to breathe after eating prawns.

wrong.text: ❌ **Incorrect.** They are having an anaphylactic shock. Water won't help.
